title: Broadchurch star David Tennant finally states his political position in this "dark time," and it's a U-turn
text:

Actor David Tennant says that he would back Scottish independence in a second referendum, in a shift from views he has expressed before. 
The 45-year-old Dr Who and Broadchurch star branded everything Brexit -related "depressing", but said he did not expect people to listen to what he said. 
Speaking to The Times Magazine, he said: "And I'm now at the point where I think if Scotland goes again for a referendum, they should go independent. 
Tennant added: "Politically, I think we're in for quite a dark time." 
Ahead of the September 2014 Scottish referendum on independence, he told the Mirror : "I feel very Scottish, I feel very proud to be Scottish. I'm very happy that Scotland conducted itself with the as much democratic dignity as it did. I'm very proud of the homeland." Back in 2011, he was even more explicit when speaking to the Guardian : "I could never understand why the SNP were banging on about it. I was like, why do we want to become smaller? Surely we want to expand and look outward? Let's go into Europe and be one big happy family!" 
The actor explained that while it was inevitable his personal views would surface during interviews, they were no more important than someone else's. 
Around the time of the last vote for independence, Tennant, who was born in Bathgate, West Lothian, reportedly said it was not for him to have an opinion as he no longer considered himself to be Scottish. 
In the September 2014 Scottish independence referendum the country voted by a margin of around 55%-45% to stay part of the United Kingdom.
